Helen Jackson Claytor papers, 1924-2005

did.abstract: Grand Rapids, Michigan, clubwoman, officer in the Grand Rapids chapter of the Young Women's Christian Association, president of the national YWCA, 1967-1973. Primarily speeches delivered on topics relating to the YWCA, civil rights, citizenship, and the family; speeches reflect in part her thoughts as a black woman on questions of school and housing segregation; and photographs.

repository.corpname: Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

acqinfo.p: The collection was the gift of Helen Jackson Claytor (donor no. 7193) and came to the library in 1984. A second acquisition was received on June 29, 2006, and came from her daughter Judith Claytor.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open to research.

userestrict.p: Copyright is held by the Regents of the University of Michigan.

prefercite.p: [item], folder, box, Helen Jackson Claytor papers, Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

bioghist.p: Helen Jackson Claytor was born April 12, 1907 in Minneapolis, Minnesota. It was here that she began her lifelong association with the Young Women's Christian Association as a member of the girl reserves. She graduated from the University of- Minnesota with an education degree in 1928.

Unable to find a teaching job, Claytor took a position with the YWCA in Trenton, New Jersey for two years and then moved to a similar position in Kansas City. There she married Earl Wilkins, a journalist and the brother of NAACP director Roy Wilkins. Claytor gave up her job until her husband became seriously ill, at which time she began to work for a black YWCA chapter in Kansas City. Following Earl Wilkins' death, Claytor accepted a position with the national YWCA as secretary for Interracial Education. In 1943, she married Dr. Robert Claytor of Grand Rapids, Michigan. After completing a study of race relations for the YWCA national board, Mrs. Claytor resigned her staff position but remained active in local and national YWCA affairs.

In 1949, Claytor was elected president of the Grand Rapids, YWCA. She was the first black woman to head an integrated YWCA chapter. She served on the national board of the YWCA, 1946-1973, and was also a member of the YWCA World Council, 1946-1952 and 1967-1972. Mrs. Claytor was elected to two terms as president of the national YWCA, 1967-1973.

scopecontent.p: The Helen J. Claytor papers primarily document her leadership in both the National and Grand Rapids YWCA, her community work on a local and national level, as well as the speeches she delivered, ca. 1940-1985, on topics relating to her activities in the YWCA, the civil rights movement, and the Episcopal Church.

controlaccess.corpname: Young Women's Christian Association (Grand Rapids, Mich.)

scopecontent.p: The first series, Biographical/Personal (approx. 1 linear feet) spans the dates 1924-2005, and includes various awards and their corresponding acceptance speeches, date books and calendars, biographical sketches and resumes, and several folders of magazine articles by or about Mrs. Claytor. Of particular note is a scrapbook chronicling her life from 1924 to 1988.

did.unittitle: The Mayor's All-America City Award January 1, 1964
Michigan Youth Commission, certificates of appointment
Helen J. Claytor Merit of Distinction Award 1983
Magazine and Newspaper Articles (by and about Helen Claytor)
Religious Faith Series in Grand Rapids Press 1955
Flair Section of the Grand Rapids Press, 2000
Aquinas College (Doctor of Humanities Honorary Degree) 1985
Eastern Michigan (Doctor of Humanities Honorary Degree) 1968
Western Michigan University (Doctor of Public Service Honorary Degree) 1972

scopecontent.p: The second series, Young Women's Christian Association (YWCA) (approx. 1.5 linear feet) spans the dates 1939-1990 and contains materials related to Helen Claytor's leadership activities in the YWCA. It is divided into three subseries: General, Grand Rapids Branch, and National Branch. General includes various newspaper clippings related to Helen Claytor's career from 1940 to 1990, her personal notes on religion and worship, as well as several professional photographs. Grand Rapids Branch, 1949-1985, includes committee materials, early Board of Director documents, and correspondence. National Branch, 1939-1989, includes general administrative materials, correspondence, as well as large topical file covering civil rights, housing, race relations, women, and youth. Of particular note is Helen Claytor's 1944 groundbreaking manuscript, "Interracial Practice in Community YWCA's."

did.unittitle: Commission to Study the YWCA as a Christian Movement
Housing: "Open Doors: A YWCA Guide for Open Housing," 1960
Institute for Leadership in Intergroup Relations 1960, 1969

scopecontent.p: The third series, Grand Rapids Community Work (approx. 1.5 linear feet) spans the dates 1952-1983, and contains materials related to Helen Claytor's community relations activities in Grand Rapid. The Grand Rapids materials, 1952-1983, are organized by topic covering education, housing, urban renewal, and busing, and includes committee materials, correspondence, personal notes, newspapers clippings, reports, and essays.

did.unittitle: Short Essay Analysis (submitted by other organizations) 1956-1963
Urban Renewal Advisory Committee (State of Michigan) 1962
Community Relations Commission, Commemorative Anniversary Celebration 1983

scopecontent.p: The fourth series, National Conferences / Committees (0.5 linear feet) spans the dates 1960-1971 and primarily documents Helen Claytor's participation in the White House conference called "To Fulfill These Rights," and include agendas, memorabilia, correspondence, newspaper clippings, reports, and photographs.

did.unittitle: To Fulfill These Rights (White House Conference) 1965-1966
Women's Advisory Committee for the Office of Economic Opportunity 1971

scopecontent.p: The last series, Speeches (approx. 1.5 linear feet), spans the dates 1940-1985. This series has been arranged in two broad categories based on the audience to which they were given. The first group includes speeches Mrs. Claytor delivered to various YWCA groups in her capacity as a YWCA staff member or officer. The speeches cover a range of topics including, the interracial practices and policies of the YWCA, the YWCA as a vehicle for social change, the YWCA position on post-World War II nationalist movements, the importance of volunteer service organizations, and the role of women and women's organizations in the United States. The second category of speeches reflects some similar themes, but was delivered to non-YWCA audiences. There are a number of speeches, ca. 1940-1981, on civil rights and racial equality in general, and several addressing the questions of school and housing segregation in Grand Rapids. Other topics include citizenship, women's organizations, the family, and religious worship.

The speeches have been foldered by individual speech title or by speech subject. Mrs. Claytor often used several versions of a speech and frequently incorporated parts of one speech into another. As a result, a text may contain several pagination sequences. An attempt has been made to reconstruct the original speech and file with it speeches that incorporated part of the original text. In some cases, the more significant speeches in a subject file have been individually cited in the contents list.
